title: If not for those irritating dogs...
review: I loved "Up": it is a great movie with some touching moments and a fantastic score. In particular the most impressive thing is the narration of the love story between Mr. Fredricksen and Ellie that is powerful even without a word because of the music and of the inspired images. The general idea of the movie is very original and the plot does a great job in entertaining the viewer. The characters are relatable and well characterised. It would have been truly an amazing movie if not for those dogs. They are so frustrating because they are so childish in a bad way. Being for children is not a problem and indeed I love animated movies but these dogs were terrible and they are used like the random NPCs you have to fight against in every videogame. And this is very bad because the messages that the movie tries to convey are important and mature and the dogs are really out of place. Even with this problem "Up" is still a great film you should watch at least once!

title: May you come out of your life and you will be a teenager
review:
Because of the entanglement of love, they put aside the adventure of traveling around the world. The stream of water is old and old, and the life of each other has been completed, and it can withstand any dream miss. Because of the stumbling block of memories, even if she died as a photo on the wall, even if he had changed from a young boy to a stubborn old man, he would have to take a once-used common hut and set sail for their childhood aspirations. The hut is the carrier of cherished memories, and the shackles of the closed heart. The adventure is a dream to get what you want. It is also a rebirth to reminisce the past. Because of a journey that has not been lost, this old man who has fallen into solitary life because of his love and death has experienced a new partner. The occasion, found a new fulcrum and new sustenance. The first ten minutes of the film described Carl's most of his life and Allie's life. I think many people's lives are similar to the first part of the film. When we were young and ignorant, we all cherished dreams of ignorance. Slowly, we are slowly worn away by life's expectations and dreams.

As Wang Xiaobo said, life is a slow process of being hammered, and finally it becomes like a hammered cow.

Their love is always with them, no matter what happens, the two are snuggling and accompany each other.

Ordinary life, but they live unswervingly, this is the simplest appearance of love. In fact, in addition to love, there are friendship, affection and nature's love. These are the seven emotions and six desires that run through a person's life. We all have to face, Carl handed over the answers to his life questionnaire about love.

Yes, Carl has become an old man, but with his love and dreams, his heart is full of blood, he was still the dream chasing boy. I think, as long as people remember their original dreams, it's never too late to start. May we run away for half our lives and return to our youth.

Regarding adventures and dreams, an old man talks about the story of a young maniac, and the dream youth and memories of an adult. The ten-minute short film and the adventures and love of Carl and Ellie throughout the film are enough to become classics, making the main line of the film seem bland. Life is an adventure, the end of this journey is not a great spectacle, but walking with you
Made me cry everytime I watch it, I just love this movie!

title: I love it
review: The strongest old grandpa and lightest house ever. A group of the most unreliable dogs and a funny bird. Plus a lovely grandma who does n't have much drama, which makes me a big love. Good movie!

title: Hit and miss home run
review:
In Up, we follow Carl Fredricksen, a widower and retired balloon salesman, who doesn't want his home to be destroyed by the development of commercial buildings, so attaches hundreds of balloons to it and flies it to Paradise Falls, him and his wife's dream destination.

Up is great. It's a fun, family film. The story is interesting and very engaging. However, the movie falls into two very obvious sections for me and I will review them as such.

The first section is the development of the story, right up to the point they reach Paradise Falls. This section is brilliant. Really great viewing. The beginning flashback sequence with Ellie is absolute perfection. It harkens back to the WALL-E and Ratatouille-esque silent story telling technique. It evokes a real sense of emotion while watching.

The second section is where Up loses steam for me. I think the humour becomes overly slapstick and for me, was hit and miss at times. Doug the dog provides comic relief and the "point" joke I found funny. However, I felt Russell became very silly. He is obviously an intelligent boy, but some of what he says and does doesn't reflect this.

However, in saying all of this, I think Up ends strongly. I really appreciate what how it wraps up and it redeemed some of my earlier grievances.

Overall, Up is brilliant. I don't think you're missing out on much if you skip it, but I still think it is worth watching.

Finally, as the house fell into the waterfall with Carl's loneliness and self-blame, he would never anesthetize himself with memories again. Because he was going to accompany a little boy to count the cars on the road.

title: About Dream and love
review:
Toward the end, Karrh watched his and Elle's house float away with a pile of colored balloons. Since Elle's death, Karrh has shut himself away from the outside world.
And finally, as the House landed safely on the edge of the cliff, he was able to let go of his obsession with the past and come out of mourning with a new Cross my heart promise. Mourning for the past should not be a shackle. It is hard to move forward by holding on to memories. Our love lives on in our hearts, our dreams live on forever, always like that small house after a long journey finally landed in the paradise waterfall above.

Anyways, outstanding film that is worth rewatching over and over and over again. 10/10

title: Pixar at its Playful, Creative, Heartfelt Best
review:
This is what the CG studio does best; dreaming up a playful, preposterous premise (whoah, way too many p's in a row there) and then riffing on it in all sorts of clever, emotionally resonant, visually incredible ways. In this case, of course, it's a cute little airborne house, suspended from a mass of festively-colored helium balloons on a sort of farewell voyage to South America.

The filmmakers don't dwell on the science of this and neither do we. It's just too much fun to second-guess, a slice of childhood imagination come to life, which fits Up's warm narrative like a cozy winter glove. That sense of freshly-rediscovered adventure, a renewed link to the open-minded optimism of our earliest memories, that's what drives the plot and binds us to the cast. Right from the picture-perfect opening scene, arguably the best dialog-free montage ever, it's got us locked in for the long haul. Even when the second act sprawls, threatening to devolve into a broad adventure tale, trailing a long tail of recurring gags, we're thrown a thematic bone to keep it all together, neat and tidy.

The traditional climax may feel just a hair on the flat side - the villain dispensed in a manner befitting a James Bond evildoer - but the story's real apex arrives just before the closing credits, when the preceding ninety minutes of small details and callbacks finally pay off in a rich, appropriate farewell.

title: Dream is not too late to start
review: Most of Pixar's animated films are about dreams, and this one is no exception. The young adventure dream and spirit have always been hidden in the heart. The death of the old wife and the ownership of the house are stimulating the old man. When he saw the adventure book again, the seeds of the dream hidden in the heart began to sprout. . Pixar animation has always given children the most extreme imagination and the best imagination, a flying house, an incredible journey, and a lifetime of love, which should be what we seek. During our growth, Pixar told We, dream, it's not too late to start.

title: Another level of storytelling
review:
During the movie I was moved several times. The animations are breathtaking, but the storytelling made 'Up' a real Pixar gem. It contains such an important message and the way they told it was simply beautiful. It felt so real and human. Loved the character development though, the little details, the montage... Especially the part in the beginning where Carl and Ellie's life was illustrated, without any dialoge. The characters are so likeable, which made me feel connected to them immediately. During happy times, I felt their joy and at the same time I cried several times - especially when Ellie died and during the ending scene.

Before I forget to mention: this movie is HILARIOUS. For sure one of my favorite Pixar movies (and man, they set the bar high).

Overall, I'm deeply impressed. I would truly recommend watching 'Up', it deserves the high ranking.

title: Perfect.
review:
There are very few movies that I can classify as being pretty much perfect. It is so refreshing to watch this movie. It has such a beautiful and original story. Plus Micheal Giacchino's absolutely gorgeous score. When I was thinking about what makes this movie so great I came up with 3 things. 1st: The opening sequence 2nd: The symbolism and 3rd: The characters

The opening sequence: This film deserves an entire section just for that montage at the beginning. It is so heartwarming and heartbreaking at the same time. It is so perfectly woven together. How it starts with Ellie waiting for Carl to get up the hill and then it switches with Carl waiting for Ellie. And that's what makes this montage so good. You go from feeling happy to sad in an instant and it feels completely natural and you don't feel jolted around. Like when they are decorating their baby's room and it is light and colorful and then the "camera" pans over to a dark and gray room that feels small and without any dialogue and you can perfectly understand that it is a miscarriage.

The symbolism: I absolutely love the symbolism of this movie. For example after Carl chooses the house over Kevin and he finally makes it to Paradise Falls, the audience doesn't feel satisfied. When Carl goes through Ellie's adventure book and see's that she actually did fill in those pages that she was saving because that was her adventure and she writes to Carl "Now go have another one." This is when Carl's ark is finally complete and he throws out all the stuff weighing the house down. Signifying that his memories were weighing him down and that he is letting go of them. It helps the audience understand the story better and it makes the scene more emotional and the audience feels that satisfaction that wasn't felt at the beginning of the sequence.

The Characters: The other two things I've talked about could not be happen without the audience being able to buy into the characters. The characters in this movie are memorable and real. What makes this movie so good is that you can buy into Carl's character the first second you see him in that theater. Probably one of the best character moments in this movie is when Carl and Russel are sitting by the camp fire and Russel tells Carl about his memories with him and his dad and when he says "Phyllis says I bother him to much" to which Carl replies "You call your mom by her first name!?" Then Russel says "Phyllis isn't my mom" Its at that point where Carl realizes that Russel isn't just trying to be a Senior Camper he is doing it so he can get those memories back with his dad. But Carl knows that that wont happen because Russel's dad left him. This scene doesn't just develop Russel as a character it is the point that starts to change Carl's heart.

This movie makes me laugh every time. Smile every time. Cry every time. The story was so carefully written and the animation is beautiful. 10/10 this movie is Perfect.

title: "I think the boring stuff is the stuff I remember the most."
review:
The first animated film to have the honor of opening the Cannes Festival. Ranked 120th on IMDb Top 250, Metascore 88, won two out of five Oscar nominations... It's good, but is it truly that good?

The story of an elderly widower who, after the death of his wife, embarks on an adventure to pursue their shared childhood dream, and learns something about himself and the true values of life. The story is well-written, emotional and laced with humorous moments, but it did not leave a particularly strong impression on me. The animation is good, with an interesting use of color, but nothing breathtaking. Everything in this movie is very good, but not great. Other than two completely unnecessarily cruel scenes (miscarriage and death of the main villain), I have nothing specific to complain about. But the movie just didn't move me. It amused me and is a handy choice if you want to watch something with younger children, but I believe soon I won't remember it at all.

7/10

title: Heart-warming family film for everyone
review:
Up, an animated Pixar film, truly captivates its viewers from the very beginning and tells the story of an old man finding a passion for life again through the adventures with an unlikely friend. Carl, whose voice is played by Edward Asner, is an older man who lives on his own, and is rather grumpy and upset with life after the passing of his soulmate, Ellie. Upon getting stuck with Russell, an upbeat boy scout an eager sense of exploration, they both embark on a journey to Paradise Falls while floating away in Carl's house. This movie is sure to excite both young and old members of the family, as it explores the practical nuances of life and getting old. The beauty of this film is the relatability and how plausible a lot of the underlying themes are for people to experience within their life. One will be hooked almost instantly, after being enticed by the cinematic editing and heartfelt moments of watching Carl's and Ellie's life together. Losing a life-long spouse, dealing with old-age and loneliness, and trying to find the beauty in life after hardships are all things that Up does a fantastic job of covering all while taking viewers on a beautiful adventure with Carl and Russell.

Russell, whose voice is played by Jordan Nagai, is a thoroughly bright spot throughout the film. Upbeat and charismatic, viewers seem to really enjoy the message Russell seems to give off; Never stop exploring and seeking things out in life. In essence, never let the child inside you fully die. While the friendship between Russell and Carl is quite odd, it is often times hilarious, especially at the beginning of the movie, and it truly shows a beautiful contrast of people's perceptions of life. His bright and bubbly attitude is only exemplified throughout the film, by subtle que's such as the bright colorful balloons used for the ship to float away, and the overall beautiful, fluorescent nature of Paradise Falls. This use of specific bright and bubbly colors shows a sense of progression or newfound appreciation for life again by Carl.

This film is sure to be an emotional rollercoaster, and genuinely speaking, the first five minutes of this film are in my humble opinion, iconic for Pixar. The film is one for everyone, and while there are moments of undoubtable children "magic", the story for this film is so magnificent, it will keep everyone intrigued throughout. In contrast with other children films, there are little that draw this much personal emotional pull. While films like Wall-E have been a big hit in the past, the relatable thematic nature of love, loss, and recovery is one everyone can connect with.

title: Beautiful, a film for all ages and stages
review:
Up left me sobbing with a smile on my face. It brought me back through all the stages of my life and had me imagining what new adventures and sorrows are yet to come. There is something for every age to connect to in this film. The uniqueness of this film is its ability to blend real dramatic content with whimsical imaginative adventure. Life is an adventure, with unexpected turns and twists and if a change is embraced happiness can be found again even after great sorrow it the powerful theme of this film.

Up, much like Mary Poppins, blends adult emotions with childlike whimsy. Mary Popping illustrates the importance of looking at life as an adventure and teaches adults to embrace change to find the happiness they too often leave behind in childhood. Mary Poppins takes the Banks children on whimsical adventures and helps Mr. Banks change. Mr. Banks ultimately finds happiness again by spending time with his family. With similar themes and techniques, both films leave their audiences lusting for a new adventure and appreciation of what they have.

Up begins and ends metaphorically and literately with the spirit of adventure. Carl Fredricksen, played by voice actor Ed Asner, it introduced in a movie hall, as he watches a film about the great adventurer Charles F. Muntz, played by Christopher Plummer. Muntz travels the world finding exotic animals on a blimp named the Spirit of Adventure. Carl meet and falls in love with Elle, played by Elizabeth Docter. Carl and Elle live a beautiful life together filled with good and bad times. They get married, buy and fix up the old house that was once the abandoned home they made their clubhouse in childhood. Scenes of sorrow are intensified using lighting techniques. They try to start a family, but Elle has a miscarriage which causes her great pain. The scene at the doctor's office when she receives the bad news is filmed from the dark hallway looking into the doctor's office, when she reflects, she sits outside in the shade. They move their focus to save for a great adventure to South America to follow the footsteps of their mutual childhood hero Muntz. As the years go by, life happens, and money is needed for unexpected expenses time and time again. When Carl finally manages to get the money together, they are elderly, and Elle ends up in the hospital where she dies. Again, lighting is used in the room before she dies is bright and the scene following at the funeral is dark to match the mood.

In this beginning montage, this film does an incredible job of invoking emotion. The deep sadness I felt for Carl after Elle died, made the transition of the film from dramatic and realistic, to fantasy easier to accept. When his house lifted in the air carried away by balloons, the sadness lifted with the house, because it brought the childlike whimsy felt when Carl and Elle first met back alive. This transition in the movie where Carl decides to have a new adventure emphasizes the central theme of this film by deciding to accept change and take another adventure.

The scrapbook Elle started as a young girl titled "My Adventure Book" is used as a visual motif throughout the film. Every time the story takes a turn and hope it needed to change and start a new adventure the book is pulled out. Music is used to intensive this visual tool, when Carl opens the book music in the background plays in the background that is associated with his love Elle. Her spirit for life is what Carl throughout the film leans on to find courage, and this powerful motif reminds the viewers of that spirit for life and courage needed to try again. After bringing the house to the spot Elle imagined so many years, he is left feeling unsatisfied and pulls out the book once more. He realizes Elle had filled pages with memories from their beautiful life together, leaving him with the advice to go out and have another adventure. The boy who by accident joined Carl on his trip to paradise is Russell, played by Jordan Nagai. Russell upset with Carl for not helping the Bird he named Kevin, goes off on a rescue mission alone. Carl realizes it is time once again to be brave and goes after him. Carl and Russel save the day and manage to return home.

The film ends with Carl standing in for Russell's father at the merit badge ceremony. The look on Russell's face when Carl pins the Elle badge on him is reminiscent of Carl's reaction years ago as a child when Elle gifted it to him. Carl, Russel, and Doug the dog played by Bob Peterson, are shown happily enjoying life together. The motif is brought out one last time and photos of the new adventures are added to "My Adventure Book". Carl was able to find strength through Elle even after her death to go out and live life again, to be courageous and because he was willing to change, he found happiness again with new friends.

title: Up
review: This perfectly demonstrates the raw talent of Pixar's writers. A movie about a house floating with a bunch of balloons should not have been good, but they found a way to do it.

title: About dealing with the past
review:
First of all, the silent opening of this film is one of the finest pieces of cinema I've ever seen. The initial meeting between Carl and Ellie, their life together and the loss at the end, is a story in and on itself. Pixar is often at its finest when there's no dialogue. And this is the crowning achievement in that. Sure, there is some dialogue at the initial meeting, but after that it's pure visual storytelling. And it is glorious!

If only the rest of the film could have been as good. And yes, I'm taking the mickey out of you. Kinda. It's still a really good film, suitable for all ages, while still retaining that core of values, depth and wisdom that marks all great Disney/Pixar films.

That being said, I'm not a huge fan of the storyline. Going to South America is fine and the fact that it is achieved with balloon is just one of those precious things that just works despite its innate insanity. Put then we get introduced to the dogs. And the birds. And Christopher Plummer's character. Which all put together leave me with mixed feelings. They're good on their own. The dogs are fun, especially Alpha and Dug. Plummer's character can be both charismatic as well as menacing. The bird is... well okay, the bird is just silly, frankly speaking. Put it's the mix of them that has the hiccups. This movie could have been this great pulp adventure. Especially if you just kept the Plummer character and got rid of the rest. Put it's not. It's simply... silly.

Not to say that the silliness doesn't work. It also helps a lot that both Carl and his junior woodchuck partner in crime Russell are both fantastic characters. Carl especially is one of my favourite Pixar characters of all time. Perfectly curmudgeon, but still extremely likable and sympathetic.

I honestly think that I might like this movie better as a whole if it didn't have that opening narration. But it has and it is so good that the rest of the film pales in comparison. Still, very much worth a watch and one of Pixar's better ones.

title: It didn't disappoint at all
review:
It's darker than the other Pixar movies but that doesn't detract from the heartwarming story and humor this movie has. The movie's about a bitter old man named Carl Fredricksen(Ed Asner) who decides to finally venture to see Paradise Falls and fulfill his deceased wife's promise after an incident almost causes him to be moved to a nursing home. Along the journey he accidentally picks up a young stowaway named Russell(Jordan Nagai) who's basically a boy scout trying to earn his next badge. In addition to having to deal with each other they come across several strange characters like a bird named Kevin and an explorer Carl used to look up to as a kid named Charles F. Muntz(Christopher Plummer).

As time goes on he begins to warm up to the kid and regain his sense of adventure. As usual the visuals look amazing. The scenes where Carl's house flies in the sky and over various landscapes looks awesome! The characters are interesting. Carl's a grump and it's perfectly understandable as to why. Russell's adorable and funny to watch which can be hard to do for kid actors. Muntz's minions which are dogs are also funny to watch. The leader of the trio sent to find the bird later revealed to be Kevin is lead by a dog who's collar is messed up so when he talks he has a high pitched voice and it's hilarious! The story can get dark at times but for the most part it's heartwarming and funny. With that being said check this movie out.

title: Up
review:
Up is an adventure film which made with Disney's classic animated formula. But when viewed from the way to tell, this film has a feeling amidst Monster Inc and The Incredibles. Synopsis this film does seem rather strange, because it presents a theme that may not be common. But in fact this film is very good, and presents a lot of humor.

This film is a story that tells the adventures of Carl and Russell who spend their floating time above the train forests of Venezuela. They have tempers, problems and obsessions.The difference in the character of Carl and Russell as a central figure in the film also becomes an attraction. Up also presents a sad opening scene and can make the audience take part in the atmosphere. Besides that, the character's animation seems cute and adorable that appeals to the audience.

This 96-minute film has a fast tempo story, but it can still be enjoyed and is not impressed jumping up and down. Even in the first ten minutes, we will feel a solid groove and no pause at all. The biggest pause we find when we are in the middle of a movie. Film Up is like teaching us to care more about our surroundings, and to always get up even after many failures. All the hidden meanings are inserted in such a way well.

Because Up is an animated film, the quality of the voice is something that must be considered. Voices like Edward Asner, Jordan Nagai and Bob Peterson, the three of them managed to turn the atmosphere on well, while still playing the role they played. Overall, this film is very worth watching for all fans of the film.

title: One of the most cool and touching animated films
review:
Story : 9 ; Characterization : 8 ; Sound Effect : 9 ; Final Value : 9/10

The film was opens with Carl Fredericksen's childhood story with Ellie. Carl Frederickson is a shy boy, but then he changes when he meets Ellie. After they grew up, they decided to get married. But unfortunately, doctors convicted Ellie could not have offspring. His wife had a dream to go to Paradise Falls in South America. Unfortunately, the wife left him first after being hospitalized. This scene what makes this movie so touching. In the midst of his sadness after Ellie left, a boy scout named Russel appeared. As a member of the wilderness explorer, Russel is trying to get the 'Helping the Elders' badge by helping Mr. Frederickson caught spike. Then, Mr. Frederickson decided to fly his own home to South America using thousands of ballons tied to the fireplace. Unexpectedly, it turns out accidentally Russel also carried away. The two of them then traveled in the jungles of South America to look for Paradise Falls.

Walt Disney always presents movies that deserve a thumbs up. Story after story that was presented, never made the audience bored and even disappointed. One of them is 'Up'. Up is an adventure animation film made with Disney's classic animated formula. Although usually animated films have a storyline that doesn't make sense this film has a pretty neat storyline. The movie that blends drama with comedy shows a story that is quite unique. The audience will never be bored watching this movie even though they are repeatedly watched. Up also presents a sad opening scene. In fact, many consider that the opening scene Up is the opening of the best movie ever. This movie is very worth watching for all movie fans. The main attraction of this movie is the flying house and the efforts of Mr. Frederickson to reach the wife's dream that is gone.

Synopsis this movie does seem rather strange, because it presents a theme that may not be common. But, in fact this movie is very good and presents a lot of humor. The diference in the character of Carl and Russel as a central figure in the movie also becomes an attraction. Besides that, film Up teaches us to care more about our surroundings, and to always rise even though we have failed many times. All of the hidden meanings are tucked in such a way that they don't look patronizing, but still highlight the messages that the film Up has.

In my opinion, Up movie goes to the list of films that are mandatory to watch. Especially if you remember Pixar's big name which has become a quality guarantee for an animated film with an interesting quality plot and a large number of meanings found in Up. When else can you enjoy movies that contain, adventure in the wild, adventure with flying balloons, and deep moral messages. Because movie Up is a film that can be watched by all ages, so you can invite anyone to watch this film.

title: A Fabulous But Uneasy Adult/Family Animated Movie
review: 5 July 2009. "Up" attempts the difficult fusion of both children and adult elements in the same movie and usually succeeds marvelously at both. This sharp, 3-D animated movie handles both roarously funny scenes along with dramatic emotional scenes dealing with love, growing old, and the issue of what's important in life. However, as a serious movie, it attempts to incorporate childlike fantasy elements and sometimes the rigors of logical and reasonable cause and effect go out the window which would be no problem in a traditional animated movie directed towards young people. But "Up" in attempting to have it both, both serious grown-up issues and thoughtful scenes, it brings with it an expectation of a tighter reign on more realistic scenes regarding chases and escapes while thrilling go beyond plausibility, breaking the suspension of animated realism, which when 3-D is used actually increases the need for virtual practical sequences. Overall however, this movie is captivated with fabulous colors, the action is riveting, the plot outline decently strong and in some instances even more intimate than Coraline (2009). 8/10.

Watch it with both your eyes and your ears. It's a masterpiece.

title: Something To Go Back To
review: The first 5 minutes of the movie are one of the best opening moments in a Disney/Pixar movie. Also the most heartbreaking, but its worth watching more than once.

title: Best movie ive seen in years!
review: This has got to be one of the most incredible movies I have seen in years. What a great storyline. Love the action, love the scenes, love the colors, the dynamics of the movie, and just the overall emotion of the movie as a whole is just down right awesome. Highly recommend watching with your kids!

title: Pixar's Greatest Adventure
review:
Everyone has big dreams. But what if those dreams are put off? Perhaps children, bills, work, even life can get in the way of people's aspirations. Carl Fredricksen's dream? To finally travel to Paradise Falls in South America in memory of his wife. The story provides a fresh and thoughtful take on the "adventure of a lifetime" that many young people crave. It diverges greatly from other Pixar films as it does not rely on outlandish characters or an unrealistic plot to keep watchers interested. Up mostly remains true to life, allowing for audiences to empathize their struggles. The film is heartwarming but is not afraid to show the grittier sides of life. Pete Docter, the director, is able to artfully balance emotional moments in the film with whimsical exhilaration which makes this movie so special. The film allows individuals to realize the morals and themes of the story on their own without feeling degraded by oversimplification. People of all ages, especially teenagers to older adults, would appreciate the light and fun approach to the serious topic of making the most out of life. For animated films, Pixar's Up represents the pinnacle of storytelling by conveying dynamic characters and a compelling plot.
 Up is intriguing due to its fresh, but familiar, storyline that allows audiences to engage in the key aspects of the movie. Just within the first ten minutes of the film, we witness Carl Fredricksen's entire childhood and adulthood leading up to the present day. The introduction contains little dialogue aside from the first interaction with his childhood friend and future wife, Ellie. Their first meeting in the clubhouse is light and humorous, a nice contrast to the following. This scene introduces the "grape soda" pin, Carl's reminder of his wife and the adventures they experienced together. After, the film cuts to a montage of Carl and Ellie's later life. All the landmarks of one's life pass before onlookers without dialogue. The melding of mellow piano music with the near dream-like scenes moves the audience to empathize with the sweet then tragic life. The film fast-forwards to a Carl now tired and grumpy with his home being encroached on by skyscrapers. Before he is forced into a retirement home, the unfortunate fate of many senior citizens, he wishes for one last adventure. He promised Ellie when they were younger they would see Paradise Falls in South America, but their plans were always put aside for more pressing issues. Their dream was ultimately never realized as Ellie fell sick and passed away. So as a final homage, Carl straps thousands of balloons to his house which floats away in the wind towards his destination. Little does he know, his adventure is abruptly interrupted by Russell. A Wilderness Survival Scout, Russell becomes a beacon of naive, hopeful spirit which reflected Carl's own childhood. The two maintain a humorous yet personal relationship throughout the film, resembling one of a grandfather and grandson. Along with talking dogs, a rare bird, and a driven explorer, Carl's straight-forward journey to the waterfall becomes more than he bargained for. The movie continues the exciting adventure to achieve his dream while contending with his stowaways and new antagonists.
 Joe Morgenstern of the Wall Street Journal found Pixar's Up to have a superficial plot and lacking some of the trademark weight that audiences expect from Pixar. However, The animated film contained a meaningful characters and story that allowed the readers to feel the quest for new beginnings on an emotional level without belittling the audience. The film contains many difficult themes such as loss, purpose, and love. The beginning exposition of Carl Fredricksen's life is heartwarming yet sets the bittersweet tone of the movie. With nearly no dialogue, we get a deep understanding of Carl's character from his childhood to time as a widower. The film has plenty of artistically planned depth and tough choices, yet it is unique to many other Pixar productions as it does not dismiss the moviegoers' intelligence by forcing morals into their face. The story rather guides audiences to make the connections and sculpt an understanding own their own. Although Mr. Morgenstern may have found Up to fall short in regards to other Pixar movies, Up displays a level of maturity, simplicity, and thoughtfulness yet to be seen by other animated films.
 The adventure of an old man and his newfound companions may seem far-fetched, but the characterization make this story profound. The ideas are well thought-out into an intelligent film that speak to the meaning of life. Although many teenagers and older adults may find the theme of this story irrelevant, it is an important question for an individual to ask him or herself. Just as the audience saw in Carl's life, all people have dreams deferred. Yet the reaction to such setbacks is unique to the individual and it creates a beautiful narrative as people saw in Up. Carl represents the best and worst within the audience's journey to find the adventure of his life.

title: Those first 15 minutes...
review: Pixar, apparently, can do no wrong. This clever and imaginative film was both funny and touching. Kids will love the fun characters and the adventure while the adults will love the quirky humor and the heartfelt story. This movie truly is fun for all.

title: Adventure is out there
review:
Young Carl idolised explorer Charles Muntz (who somehow looks a lot like Kirk Douglas) and his discovery of Paradise Falls somewhere in South America. Others regarded him as a quack and a fake, so Muntz disappeared.

Carl wanted to be an adventurer, he met young Ellie who was even more adventurous but real life got in the way. Now Ellie has passed and Carl is a grumpy old man living alone, hounded by property developers who are bull dozing the neighbourhood and want to see him in a retirement home.

Carl has tied his house with loads of helium balloons to float to Paradise Falls. He manages to take with him, an unwitting boy scout Russell who was just helping out an elderly person for a badge.

Both find adventures including a rare bird, talking dogs and a fallen hero. More importantly Carl finds a yearning for life as he hangs out with young Russell who himself is freindless.

I ended up viewing this film as my wife took our kids to the cinema to watch this and upon her return she told me that I would end being like Carl went I am older. I guess it is a roundabout way of telling me that I am a grouch!

The film starts with a segment of Carl and Ellie from childhood to old age. It is the junior Carl who is shy, slightly awkward, a pace or two behind the frenetic and energetic Ellie. As life goes on, they could not have children and it is Ellie who slows down as they get older and she passes on, leaving Carl on his own.

It is all about Carl rediscovering that zest for life and having that adventure he and Ellie dreamt about all those years ago. This is a fun and imaginative film, slightly surreal and off beat. For a film called UP it actually keeps its feet on the ground in terms of story and emotion.

title: So good
review: THIS MOVIE IS FANTASTIC OH MY GOSH. The first 10 minutes are a real tear jerker though, so get your tissues ready ladies.

title: I love this movie
review: I wanna see this movie because I didn't see this move

review: If you love animated movie, but some how you missed to watch it, than don't waste any more time! Site Down. and watch the movie. I can ensure, you won't regret. <3

title: Touching the void
review:
I'm 15 years old and this movie make my eyes watery.

It's was hard for me to go back to reality after watching this "touch-hard-movie" is just more than just a simple word. There's no word to describe what it's feels to watch this movie.

title: NEWS FLASH!
review: This is a really great movie, but not everyone is gonna like it as you can see others don't like it because "HOW IS A HOUSE FLOATING BY HELIUM BALLOONS" like come on this is Disney anything can happen! It's Pixar animation come on everyone knows that's due sh is for people who actually have imaginations unlike others and it's not really meant to be taken too literal like come on common sense we all know a house can't float by helium balloons, but in imagination anything can happen. TOTALLY RECCOMMEND THIS MOVIE

title: good
review: The beginning is the only god part and it made me ball my eyes out. the reason why such high rating is because the beginning is the best thing i've ever seen in my life.

title: Reflection time
review: Another winner from the Pixar team. Soul searching, tragedy, triumph it has it all. We all need a Doug in ours lives.

title: simply wow movie
review: This animation movie really amazing and fully enjoyable. thanks again to the creator for help us to pass some good time with 'UP'!!

title: Would recommend
review: Often we don't expect certain movies to mean anything. This one was enjoyed by my entire family and tought a great lesson. Emotional roat coaster.

title: Up with your dream
review:
Up demonstrates the importance of creativity, vision, intention, and especially the power of commitments made with like-minded spirits. The love Carl and Ellie felt for each other was palpable throughout the movie even without words, just music. Their love included trials and tribulations, including a child lost mid-pregnancy, which helped evoke a full spectrum of emotion around the theater.

Ellie becomes sick and dies, leaving Carl, now an older man named Mr. Fredricksen, to live their adventure solo. He works to keep Ellie's spirit alive for himself with photos, scrapbooks, memorabilia, and imagined conversationsâ€”the same creative play that first brought them together.

title: "Adventure is out there!"
review: I'm not particularly a fan of animated movies, but once settled in I can generally find them entertaining and worthwhile. The same can be said for "Up", the tale of an old widower curmudgeon who inadvertently hijacks a stowaway on his sky-bound home as it lifts off for a lifelong destination called Paradise Falls. The film is colorfully rendered, and if you're a guy who once might have been involved in Scouting at any level, you'll get a kick out of Carl Fredricksen (voiced by Ed Asner) sending his young hitchhiker Russell (voiced by Jordan Nagai) on a hopeless snipe hunt. When these things occur, I find myself in the underdog's corner, and when Russell finds a snipe and names him Kevin, the adventure really gets under way. It's too bad Carl's childhood hero turned out to be a villain, but that sets up the challenge of saving his new found friends from a diabolical, mad scientist, and find a way to get back home. Oh yeah, can't forget the cute canine pal along for the ride as well. His name is Dug, and is sort of the comedy relief character along with Kevin, and has a big hand (paw?) in making the save for the intrepid travelers. For it's efforts, "Up" won a Best Animated Feature Film at the Oscars in 2010 against some worthy contenders. In it's own way, the film has something for young and old alike, and if you're feeling down for any reason at all, you might even find it up-lifting.

title: To the skies in a house with thousands of balloons!
review:
I like an adventurous adventure. I've heard everyone needs someone to look up to - and Carl Fredricksen idolising famous explorer Charles F. Muntz certainly demonstrates this, as does Muntz vowing not to return until he captures an exotic bird at Paradise Falls. Carl befriending a girl named Ellie, also a Muntz fan is interesting to watch and I like two would-be explorers sharing their desire of a great adventure together.

I was moved by Carl and Ellie's emotional experiences during their years together. They realised their dream of visiting Paradise Falls, but I wasn't expecting Ellie to fall ill and die. Some may think that because elderly people are elderly, they're adventures are over. But that's never a guaranteed fact: I'd seen the posters for Up before I saw the film and when I first saw the thousands of helium balloons lifting Carl's house up to the skies, I was truly amazed. Russell, a young Wilderness Explorer who visited Carl in his effort to earn his final merit badge, becomes an accidental stowaway as he frantically pleads to be let in but is denied by Carl at first, which I found hilarious!

The house flying through a thunderstorm is tense to watch, but the flying house survives and lands on a tepui opposite Paradise Falls. Carl and Russell harness themselves to the still-buoyant house and walking it across the mesa is a good idea. I love the tall, colourful flightless bird known as the mythical "Snipe", whom Russell names "Kevin". The Golden Retriever named Dug, who wears a special collar that allows him to speak is also great. The pack of aggressive dogs led by Alpha, a Doberman Pinscher, are fun to watch. I was taken by surprised that Alpha had a funny voice, which turned out to be broken wire in Alpha's collar. I wasn't expecting Muntz to become the film's villain in his search for a giant bird. I was concerned for "Kevin" and Carl's house, when Muntz forced Karl to choose between saving it or Kevin. I was relieved Carl saved his house and that he and Russell reached the falls, but I felt for Russell and I was also concerned for Kevin. Carl looking through Ellie's childhood scrapbook is another fantastic moment - looking back at memories can be very powerful and have positive reminders of happy times.

When one adventure ends, another adventure begins. Russell going to rescue Kevin lifted my spirits - as did Carl lightening his house to take to the skies once again. The final showdown on Muntz airship is tense, but fun to watch. I was relieved once more when Carl freed Russell and Kevin. Dug inadvertently saddling Alpha with his cone of shame and becoming the dogs' new leader made me laugh and proud. Muntz falls to his death and Carl's house descends out of sight through the clouds. Carl could not have said it better, "It's just a house."

After reuniting Kevin with her chicks, Carl and Russell fly back to the city. Carl presenting Russell with his final badge: a grape soda cap that Ellie gave to Carl when they first met is a proud moment. I was very pleased that Carl's house landed on the cliff beside Paradise Falls, fulfilling his promise to Ellie. Towards the end of 2009, I had a feeling that a powerful experience was approaching. And Up certainly played a flying part leading Up to that powerful experience!

title: A great one for the whole family
review:
The humour of this movie is such a great one that everyone will enjoy watching it!

The story is such a good one that the kids will learn a thing or two about our world and other (older) people. We as adults will also enjoy the story for its beautiful simplicity. A back to basics that will remind us how to properly behave with each other. The world would be a better one if some of this movie's lessons were applied more often in our everyday life.

9 out of 10 for a movie no one will regret seeing, regardless of age.

title: Just my thoughts on the movie
review: It was all right, I mean the story was good but I tend to over think movies and compare them with reality which makes movies worse. Yes I know that the shift from reality makes these movies, movies. For example Star Wars (or any Sci Fri movie for that matter) would be sh!t if you compared it to the real world. But Up however looks like it's supposed to look like the real world, if that makes sense. Now before we start this may contain spoilers it just depends on how much you know about the movie. First off Pixar animations admitted to have calculated how many helium balloons would have been needed to lift up and fly away with the house and yet didn't animate enough balloons in the film, what were all the calculations for? And also did you just happen to have a bunch of helium balloons cramped together in a chimney and if so how did the house not take off already (it's been a while since I saw the movie, I remember most of it with my photographic memory but I can't remember if this was explained in the movie). And lastly, if you think about it the old dude basically kidnaps the little Boy Scout and just flies off.

title: A real treat for the whole family
review:
UP is a wonderful, heartwarming movie for all of the family. This tear jerking story will leave you both crying and laughing and most definitely wanting more!

I highly recommend this for a family movie night just make sure to have the tissues in hand as you may shed a tear or ten.

title: Its lovely and real
review: I watched this movie on 2012 may be, with my wife. Now, we are living in different countries because of our work. We still remember the movie and talk about it sometime. We have a son, we showed this movie to him as well. He enjoys watching this movie. Simply awesome! Thanks for this movie.

title: Up is an adventurous animation that has a comic element that engages people of all ages.
review:
UP is a Pixar movie that has Ed Asner's voice for Carl Frederickson who is an old man that has dreamed of going to Paradise Falls, South America his whole life. After his wife Ellie dies he gets into some trouble and is sent to a retirement home. Before they can take him there he uses balloons to lift his house and floats all the way to Paradise Falls. Carl ends up with a stowaway boy named Russell voiced by Jordan Nagai and ends up having the adventure of a lifetime. During this big adventure they end up meeting up with Carl's childhood idol Charles Muntz voiced by Christopher Plummer. Charles is an adventurer that was discredited and disappeared to Paradise Falls to regain his good name. As Pixar only makes animated movies with themes that seem to engage all ages the closest related theme I can relate to this is the theme of Despicable Me, where the older person in each end up loving the child or children involved. Although this movie uses computer-generated imaging it engages people of all ages with the antics of Russell and the crabbiness of Carl. They have all the typical problems of a grumpy grandfather type and that of a young boy even though they are not related. The dialog between Carl and Russell is typical for the age difference between them. They argue and fight about almost everything.

The lighting used for this movie is both high-keyed and low-keyed. The low-keyed lighting is used mostly during the scenes in South America where as the high-keyed lighting was used mostly in town before the adventure really starts and when the house is floating through the sky. The adventures are plenty rich with ups and downs. They are a combination of comedy and excitement. Carl and Russell end up saving a bird that Carl thinks is a nuisance to begin with. Then a talking dog comes into the picture too. This also makes Carl more irritable. Both animals are comical and almost believable. A villain that makes Carl not so grumpy with Russell also enters the picture. Pixar did an amazing job on this movie with a story line that could just be believable. You have grumpy old Carl and annoying little Russell against the wondrous world of Paradise Falls. With both of them trying to overcome their own obstacles in life. Written by A Anslow

title: The Spirit Of Another Moving Pixar Masterpiece
review:
My chances of seeing this film were so slim until one day before I graduated from middle school at the time, I saw this movie with my younger sibling along with some friends of his from elementary school, hoping that we would have a great time. Then, after the movie ended, we had such a great time. Never, and I mean, never have I seen another masterpiece from Pixar and this is in the same depth as the Toy Story trilogy, The Incredibles, Monsters INC and Finding Nemo.

The characters are very likable. Carl Fredricksen is a charming old man and I liked his attempts to reach Paradise Falls to make his deceased wife's dreams come true. Russell is also likable and the scene where he explains that his parents are divorced made me felt sorry for him. Dug, a dog with a device that can allow him to speak, is hilarious as is the humorous moments with him and a prehistoric bird named Kevin is also great and I liked the way he runs so fast which makes his speed much more incredible than you would expect from other animals. I also like the dogs, but I like the villain Charles F. Muntz as the best character in this film. The reason why I like him is because you think that he might by a good protagonist, but when he explains his evil ways of capturing the bird, you know that's the reason why you'll have a great villain to love. The voice cast, including Edward Asner, Christopher Plummer, Jordan Nagai and Bob Peterson (the screenwriter for the film) voiced the characters pretty well.

The story is very original. It had some heart-wrenching moments including the beginning part where Carl's wife dies after so many attempts of getting some money to go to Paradise Falls and it's so sad that it would always make you feel sorry for Carl. It also has some witty and hilarious dialog including the moments with the dog leader's voice which sounded like a chipmunk along with Dug, but not only that. It has some intense action moments with the characters which is also a good thing throughout the whole film. The music from Michael Giacchino is also pretty good too. It has a great mixture of light-hearted moments and some intense moments.

What stands out the most is the animation. It is so beautiful you can see that every detail is unique and realistic, but the strongest aspect of the animation is the look of Paradise Falls because it really wows you to see that it can take your very breath away in about a few seconds. The character animation/design is also beautiful and I like the way some of the human characters and animal characters are supposed to feel like actual people in every ordinary lives.

Overall, Up is Pixar's another masterpiece in the history of animation and it's great to see that a year later, Dreamworks Animation made their masterpiece "How To Train Your Dragon" and it's also a great film to watch just like this one.

title: Up a bright colorful movie packed with adventure
review: The movie "Up" is another wonderful Pixar film. I found it to be very entertaining as well as giving a good storyline for people of all ages. However the beginning was not my favorite I did however overly enjoy the rest of the movie. I loved the fact that the film was very bright and cheerful and full of adventure. Carl (Edward Asner) is a stubborn old man that is stuck in his ways and really does not seem to like people. Russell (Jordan Nagai) is a wilderness explorer who is bound determined to get his assisting the elderly badge. However, Russell did not know that he was about to be on a wild adventure with a 70 year old man, in a house flown by balloons. Carl did not expect to be on an adventure with anyone else, let alone run into a talking dog and a bird that Russell named Kevin. The theme to the movie "UP" is to never give up on your dreams and what you want out of life. Russell will not give up on getting his assisting the elderly badge and Carl will not give up on Ellie's dream. The theme of this movie matches the theme in the movie the "Incredibles", with never giving up on your dreams and what you want out of life. There are many techniques in the movie "Up" that show us the theme of the movie. The lighting is very bright and cheerful that goes against the gray old face of Carl. The angles in the movie make you feel like you are a part of the action. When they are flying in the air and have to go a different direction, you feel as if you are in the house as well. The angels also help you too see the reactions off all of the people involved. I think that this film gave you a good sense on the fact that if you stick with what you want to do in life that in one way or another you can and will get the job done. Russell and Carl were both faced with tough obstacles that kept getting in the way of what they wanted to accomplish but they always seemed to get through them. I think that this is a good kid's movie on how hard sometimes you have to work just to get a wilderness explorer badge.

title: An amusing and unusual group of adventurers
review:
In the beginning of the animated film, Up, we are introduced to two young, enthusiastic and very different children who share a passion for traveling and their hero, renowned traveler and explorer Charles Muntz. This connection leads Carl Fredricksen, voiced by Ed Asner, and Ellie to become best friends as well as husband and wife. Their passion for travel never abates and they spend their life saving money to travel to Paradise Falls. Unfortunately, as it often does, life gets in the way and their dream is never reached.

Fast forward many years and we find an old, stubborn, grouchy Carl as the world has changed rapidly and left him disgruntled and refusing to change with it, reminiscent of Walter Mathau and Jack Lemmon in Grumpier Old Men. Refusing to sell his house he mistakenly causes harm to someone, which gets him in trouble with the law and he is forced to live in a retirement community. Refusing to let this get in his way, he manages to inflate thousands of balloons tied to his house, which causes his how to rise up and float away. His destination: Paradise Falls. It's at this point that the theme of the movie really begins to pick up: no matter what happens, life goes on and you should enjoy every minute of it because you don't know what will happen next.

While flying to Paradise Falls, he hears a knock on his door, and unbeknownst to him, a local member of the "Wilderness Explorers", Russell has accidentally been brought along. Having no choice but to bring Russell along, he navigates them safely through a massive thunderstorm and almost arrived at his destination. Many balloons were lost in the storm and although still floating, it is not able to fly at high altitudes so Carl and Russell must drag the house to its final location.

On the trek across the mountainous terrain Carl and Russell encounter an exotic bird and a talking dog that is trying to capture the bird and return it to his master. During this trip the exotic bird runs away because they encounter many other talking dogs and they are escorted to a remote cave where Carl is united with his idol, Charles Muntz, who has spent the better part of his life searching for the elusive exotic bird that has befriend the group. Upon learning this Carl finally shows some emotion and spends the remainder of the film trying to prevent Charles from harming the bird.

This film used amazing computer graphics and enhanced colors to bring a mesmerizing setting to the viewer's eye. The focal point of this movie was the balloons that Carl used to float his house away and you can tell special attention was given to the creation and design to create an impressive display on the screen. The vividness they used also translated into Carl and his grumpy face and the transformation he goes through and without this superior artwork, they would have been unable to truly capture the essence of Up and the central theme of the film of how life goes on and to not waste a minute of it.

title: Good Story
review:
I can't believe that I'm reviewing a cartoon; but what the hell, maybe my second childhood is near. Carl Fredricksen(Ed Asner) was a lonely little boy who worships an explorer named Charles Muntz, a man who was disgraced for faking the discovery of a big bird in Venezuela. He meets Ellie, a neighbor who shares his passion for nature. When they grow up they marry, but are unable to have children. He sells balloons and she works at a zoo. They have always intended to travel to South America to verify Muntz's claims to clear his name. The best laid plans of mice and men prevent it and Elle dies, leaving Carl alone. His house is surrounded by a new development, but he refuses to leave. He injures a construction worker in a dispute, and receives an eviction notice.

He comes up with the idea to attach thousands of helium balloons to lift the house into the air and fly it to Venezuela and fulfill his dream of finding Muntz's bird. He takes off with a stowaway, Russell, who is trying to earn a merit badge by helping the elderly. They meet a non flying bird and a talking dog along the way. They make it to their destination and find Muntz living in a zeppelin. They end up in a fight over the bird and, not to worry, this is a children's story, so all's well that ends well.

title: My favorite Pixar film so far.
review: "Up" was a great triumph for Pixar, and for animated films in general. Any animated film can make the target audience (children) laugh- -add a couple of cheap jokes and the kiddies roll with laughter. But "Up" does much more than that. It makes you cry as well. I highly regret that my family and I went to see Disney's farce of "G-Force" instead of this in theaters. Don't get me wrong, "Up" has plenty of humor as well, but this film goes one step more and plays with your deeper emotions. This film explores the theme of letting go of the past and embracing the future. There's plenty of drama for adults, plenty of fun and action for children. Be cautious of letting very small children watch this, but it should be fine for most kids. By all means, watch this movie. It's a testimony to the power of animation.

title: Up - A wonderful film for all ages
review:
Adventure is out there! Or so Carl Fredricksen (Edward Asner) once believed. After his beloved wife of many years, Ellie, passes, Carl begins to regret not travelling with her on their great adventure: to Paradise Falls, South America. Feeling lonely and increasingly closed in by the rest of the growing world, Carl ties thousands of balloons to his small house and takes off into the skies toward South America! So begins Carl's final adventure, which is the subject of the wonderful film by Pete Docter and Bob Peterson: Up.

Not long after "take off" Carl finds a stow-away aboard his house, the young "Wilderness Explorer" Russell (Jordan Nagai). Carl has no choice but to continue on with his new companion, and together they embark on a thrilling adventure. There are chases, near escapes, dastardly villains, talking dogs, and giant birds, but the real discovery for Carl is that life is the greatest adventure of all. This is the primary theme of Up.

The high point of the film actually comes toward the beginning during a prologue (of sorts) that details the lives of Carl and his wife Ellie. The technique used is a wonderful montage depicting how they meet, their marriage, and all of the joy (and heartbreak) that follows. This short opening truly captures Carl and Ellie's love of adventure and the realization that their greatest adventure would never come. Only later, after travelling to South America and all appears to be lost, does Carl realize the true adventure was all of the time spent with Ellie.

Another technique used by the film to heighten the sense of adventure is the angles used in certain shots. The angles used when on the porch of Carl's house, or on top of an airship, add a great feeling of verticality that makes you believe the characters are in real peril. Even though it's an animated film, the danger is palpable, even though you never truly believe one of our "heroes" would fall.

Like Wall-E before it, Pixar's Up is a much more personal story. We do not follow a huge cast of wise-cracking talking zoo animals. Instead we follow an old man and a young boy on their journey. Their journey is Carl's journey, and Carl's journey leads him to discover that adventure is not "out there"; his adventure has been his entire life.

title: Up, Down, Turn around - This is a classic movie!
review:
When I woke up this morning, my eyes burnt red like an early mornings sky in November. The question I'm sure your thinking is why? Why did my eyes burn red?

I'll tell you why - I had eaten 6 raw potatoes, washed down with the Diesel from my mother's 1969 Chevy the night before. I am currently aware that this was not a wise or well thought-out decision to make, but life is all about learning from ones mistakes.

This left my Kidneys burning inside me like they had been set on fire with a naked flame, and left me bed ridden for the best part on two weeks and in the duration of this two weeks I had the time and opportunity to watch a wide variety of films, and then review them for the world to see; that is my story, and now it's yours. (Feel free to tell it as an anecdote at intimate family reunions.)

The first of many motion pictures that I had the pleasure of viewing was "Up". Pixar's brand new animation that had such good reviews, when reading them my eyes literally set on fire. (that's another story for another day). The animation was outstanding, blatantly showing the advances in modern day technology - A credit to Pixar and there team of elves working behind the scenes.

The film provoked a wide range of emotional responsive from myself and my imported Greek, smart alec cat, including moments of sadness, moments of uplifting joy and the inevitable provoking of blind rage.

Overall, I think this was a top notch film. If I had created it all by myself with just a pen and a dream I would be well happy!

Peace out, and on a very similar note,

Movieman out.

title: Thumbs Up: Entertaining cartoon for all the family
review:
I saw this cartoon with my son on cable for the first time. We spent an entertaining evening.

I have to admit that the storyline was nicely done. The characters were well developed especially the one of the old man. The dogs therefore came too cheap and could have been presented in another way here.

I have never seen such a beautiful story before transformed in an animated movie. It's really worth a watch.

It is fast paced and I was never bored cause I was asking all the time what would come next.

Final vote: 9/10

title: How does Pixar keep doing it?
review:
It's amazing how Pixar keeps making great animated films. They are somehow able to find that magic of compelling storyline, heart-felt characters, great voice actors, lively and light-hearted animation, and meaningful musical scores. Whatever magic potion they've got over there is really working. Dreamworks has been hit and miss. The other companies pale in comparison.

Where to begin? How gutsy was Pixar to have a septuagenarian as one of its lead characters? And to top it off, deal with emotional gut wrenching themes of loss; through miscarriage, death of a loved one, and potential loss of a lifelong home. They spice things up by adding a young boy who's dealing with his own issues of abandonment, emotional distance from a father, and striving to achieve. Wow. Heavy stuff for a kids film. And yet Pixar pulls it off, making a film highly entertaining for young ones (my 6 yr old was captivated) and their parents.

Just when you think things are getting too heavy, a change of pace comes along with the introduction of a group of dogs with collars that allow them to "speak", as well as the antagonist of the story. A few chase scenes, some funny scenes, some serious bonding and voilÃ . A fantastic family adventure movie that ranks among the best ever made by any animation company.

9/10

title: An Instant Classic!
review:
I remember watching this movie, and I was truly struck with the warm feelings and complete and utter satisfaction. I can't remember the last time I was so pleased with a cartoon.

Even though I am an overall fan of Pixar, this must be their best work as of yet! An astounding movie with riveting animation and colors, beautifully composed music, synchronizing perfectly with the setting and mood - not to mention an absolutely, unforgettably heartfelt plot.

Approximately five minutes into the movie I was sitting still, trying to hold back my tears. The entire story is a roller-coaster (truly) of emotions from sadness to roaring laughter.

I don't think anyone could possibly regret seeing this, as I personally think it would be worth the money and time to see a couple times more. A wonderful story and proof that animation is not simply for children! It is a story everyone can relate to, and will definitely be a remembered experience for both the young and the old.

How they managed to create a story which is so imaginative and real at the same time is beyond my comprehension - but I was impressed, and this is an instant classic for years to come!

title: Heartwarming Adventure!
review:
Up is a big, warm-hearted animation with great visuals, humor, and many realistic things. Of course, it's not based on the truth. There ain't a chance in hell that it is based on the truth. But this movie is so beautiful because it focuses a lot on the main character. Also, I found the film to very sad at the beginning, but at the end, it puts a huge smile on your face. I can assure you.

Carl Fredrickson(voiced brilliantly by Ed Asner) had a good life for a while. Until he got older. Now that Carl is older, his life is kind of sad. His wife has passed, the neighborhood in which he lives in has turned into a construction site, and he is very lonely. One day as he is going to go to a retirement home, he decides to escape in his house which is tied up to a billion balloons, and fly out to where he always dreamed of going.

So as Carl is traveling, he realizes that there is a boy scout on the house that is flying with him. So, him and Russell land in South America, and find a bunch of weird stuff. Including dogs who have voice box leashes, and other things.

Up is a fantastic film. I think that this movie is so cute and funny that I could just eat it up. For a long time, Ratatouille was the best of Pixar's works. I know Wall E and others were good, but Ratatouille was better. Now, Pixar has made something that tops even that movie. Up is one of the best films of the year.

title: absolutely beautiful
review:
Pixa is literally brilliant. Creative ideas, advanced technology, ability to tell the story, all is great. Even before the movie really started, I was already deeply moved by the short story of clouds and storks. Pixa may be one of the best which know about human emotion and feeling for priceless things.

For me, the most amazing moment of Up is in the first 15 minutes. With the old album showing Carl and Ellie's photos, I could see how much they have cared for each other, and how much they have dreamed. This scene is very well created. The colorful and beautiful balloons from Up will not be forgotten for a long time. Up realizes the dream, which anyone probably have had in his or her life, for the person. After watching it, I felt like I traveled somewhere very exotic and fantastic.

title: a heartwarming 3D movie
review: it is a heartwarming 3D movie it is a touching movie for the whole family UP is one of the biggest movies ever crested in 3D it is a feel good movie you will just stand up and cheer after it is over it is that good you will say now that was a sad movie it is a feel good movie of the year i think and lets talk about the 3D now the 3D was out of this world the movie it self was out of this world too it is a funny movie i never saw a movie like this this is a movie for the whole family UP is one of the coolest films ever created it has the perfect amount of action you will just go crazy over one of the best movies on earth it is a hot movie because this movie won a lot i mean a lot of awards now that is a great movie if it won awards this is one of the biggest films of 2009 this movie is a heartwarming,touching,amazing movie it is the best Disney Pixar film ever created you will say OK we got to watch that again this movie is a sweet hart movie you will just start crying have a outstanding day everyone

title: Grows on You
review:
This is one of those movies you have to see several times to get all the nuances and gags.

This movie spoofs a lot of movies and salutes a lot of traditional values.

The score is perfectly suited to the action.

It is amazing that the animation and the score can telegraph emotion as well as it does.

While a number of the things that happen in this movie would not stand up to scientific scrutiny, the plot is so engaging that it is easy to suspend belief after the original liftoff.

When many other animated movies offer up dialog that borders on the smutty just for a laugh, this is a breath of fresh air by comparison.

All in all, a good way to spend an hour and a half or so.

Anybody notice that Charles Muntz looks like a caricature of Kirk Douglas?

Squirrel!

title: Lovely experience
review: Lovely for the game between dreams of childhood and the facts of old age. Poetry in skin of nostalgic nuances. Comedy and emotional travel, adventures with Jules Verne taste and bridges between visions of a child and an old man.The empty heard of dream and forms of escape. Mixture of feelings, colors and ingenuity. And delicate form to tell a special story, no different of many others but full of lights of life sense.A movie for lost ages. Or guide for teenagers.Picture of soul steps and discover of basic parts of happiness. Map of way of life and scene of balloons fly. A snail and its wings. And the beauty of truth behind any appearance. The rest - silence. Joy of an experience .

title: It is a lovely story but why the animation?
review:
Now there are things that couldn't be done with live actors but CGI has changed that and it left me wondering why this very lovely story was produced as an animation. For the first half of the story there seemed no earthly reason why, and even in the second half I was still wondering.

Perhaps it was in the marketing as a 3D production that we are treated to camera angles and shots that would be quite difficult to achieve in live action and that is a pity because the story stands up on its own and is overplayed in many of the animation sequences. Fortunately it doesn't spoil the entertainment value but I am left thinking it reduces what could have been a great film into a good one.

Yes the spectacle is, in places, a visual treat, but there is something missing in the personalities that the film doesn't quite make up for. And so I am awarding it seven out of ten for entertainment value, with three out of ten deducted for trying to divvy up reasons for three dimensional viewing.

title: Pixar has done it again!
review:
First off, let me jut say that this is not my favourite film from Pixar. "Finding Nemo" and the "Toy Story" movies, especially the third one, go into that slot.

That being said, "Up" does not disappoint. It is basically about a 70-year-old man who decides to tie thousands of balloons to his house and go to a beautiful place called "Paradise Falls," a place where he had always dreamed to go.

Everything is beautiful here, but what truly makes the magic of the movie is the acting. You really feel for the characters, and their voices, especially Ed Asner's character. After going through a lot of things in his life, you can just tell from the start that he has always loved adventure, but has always been stuck in the same old house. Christopher Plummer, whose character does not come in until later on in the movie, is great is the movie's antagonist; I've only really known him from "The Sound of Music," so it was great to see, or should I say "hear", him play something else.

All in all, a very beautiful movie. The only reason why it was not as good as "Finding Nemo" and the Toy Story movies is simply because of the fact that I grew up with those movies (except for the third toy story, in which I re-visited my childhood when watching that movie). But, overall, I can't complain here. 9/10 for me.

title: "Up, up, and away"
review:
By tying thousands of balloon to his home, 78-year-old Carl Fredricksen sets out to fulfill his lifelong dream to see the wilds of South America. Right after lifting off, however, he learns he isn't alone on his journey, since Russell, a wilderness explorer 70 years his junior, has inadvertently become a stowaway on the trip.

The first 20 minutes put me in tears. I was literally feeling for these animated characters, it was almost scary. This movie contains so much heart it isn't even funny. Aside, the film starts and get ready for an adventure of a life time. Pixar has ONCE AGAIN proved that they can combine elements for both kids and adults without being to lean on it. I sincerely love them and hope they continue with their projects. Up, in fact, is not my favorite but is up there with Walle and Ratatouille. Pixar has many imaginative ideas such as a family of superheros, a cooking rat, or a trash-cleaning robot but never have I heard of an animation of an old man. But only Pixar can pull it off. People become skeptical and irritated of the introduction of the dogs. For one, I think those people thought as Up as an adult film. NO WAY! Up is obviously a kid's movie and that is what it was marketed for, but the balance between both is great. The animation is beautiful, with comparing to their earlier projects is mind-blowing of how much improvements they have made. Well, that is mostly it. Up is a great step up for Pixar and I suspect better and more mature movie from them. You know, ones that do not include dogs flying planes. But aside from that, the film is near-perfect. 9/10.

title: Must See Movie!!!
review:
The makers of Monsters Inc. and Finding Nemo (Pixar Animation Studios of Walt Disney Pictures) compose another hilarious and heart-warming masterpiece. This movie will make you laugh, cry, and laugh some more. Up has all features that make a movie great: action, thrills, passion, laughs, love, and adventure.

Ex-adventure seeker Carl Fredrickson is a balloon salesman retiree and just wants him and the house he and his wife Ellie built to be left alone. After an incident with a construction worker, Carl is ordered to leave his dream house for a retirement home. But Carl has different ideas. He attaches hundreds of balloons to his house to get out of the troubled area and out to the place where he and his wife dreamed of taking their house to, Paradise Falls in South America. Russell, a young boy-scout, accidentally ends up on Carl's porch and tags along on the adventure. They meet new friends such as talking dog Doug and a large mysterious colorful bird that Russell names "Kevin". Along the way, they find Carl's childhood idol, adventurist Charles Muntz. After having dinner with Muntz, Russell begins to talk about their new friend Kevin and how he follows him. Unknown to Russell, "Kevin" is the only reason that Muntz is in South America. Carl is thrilled to see meet childhood hero, he realizes Muntz is out to kill Kevin. So Carl ends up trying to help Kevin.

This movie is by far one of my all-time favorites, a must see. It has an amazing story with outstanding animation and is a hilarious movie that is fun for the whole family. If you know somebody that doesn't like animated cartoons, show them this masterpiece.

title: genuine masterpiece
review:
they make 1 film a year minimum and most of the time they really are lacking in a lot of ways.

This film however is a masterpiece of its genre fit for all ages and tastes, acquired or not, it shows almost every emotional quality possible in just one storyline and the artwork isn't too bad on the eyes either, primarily a fun happy film (of course) the fact it had me drop a tear is saying something, especially for a child's film.

the first 10 minutes of this film are simply breath taking, it really does have you sucked in instantly and the character development is so accurate yet subtle, i really did find myself immersed in the film, there's a few cheekys that the younger generation wont get and of course there's many gags that are executed perfectly

well done pixar you've redeemed yourself for a few more years, good job!

title: Love is an Adventure
review:
Up is a fantastic story about love and the spirit of adventure. When a cautious young Carl (Jeremy Leary) meets the adventurous Ellie (Elie Docter), the two begin a sweet and loving relationship that lasts until Ellie's death. A short time later Carl (Edward Asner) realizes that the outside world is no place for him and he decides to chase the dream that he and Ellie shared. When faced with having to move from the home that he and Ellie built, he blows up thousands of balloons with hopes of flying in the house to Paradise Falls. This begins a wild adventure that includes a stowaway (Russell voiced by Jordan Nagai), dogs, and a strange bird.

This beautifully told story shares a story of two people who love each other very much and who share a common dream. Even when Ellie dies, Carl finds a way to show his love for her by going on this journey to Paradise Falls.
